articles.title: Kindling Equity
articles.contents:
Climate change is increasing the frequency and severity of wildfires across California, and there is an urgent need for wildfire preparedness and response in Ventura County, California. Simultaneously, historically-excluded communities disproportionately lack access to resources and services to prepare for and recover from wildfires. As a result, they have a heightened risk of human suffering and property loss in the event of wildfire.
In collaboration with the Ventura Regional Fire Safe Council, our project seeks to identify communities most at risk of wildfire impacts in Ventura County and to help update the Community Wildfire Protection Plan so that it equitably addresses community needs.
We will contribute to the field of wildfire management by providing a model that local governments and organizations can utilize to address social equity concerns in the wildfire planning process. Our goal is to demonstrate effective methods for developing an accessible wildfire management plan that engages impacted residents to reduce local wildfire risk and increase community resilience with implications beyond Ventura County.
Read our work plan

articles.title: Kindling Equity
articles.contents:
Kindling Equity is a team of Master’s students from the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management at the UC Santa Barbara that is interested in bringing equity to the wildfire planning and mitigation process.

We are partnered with the Ventura Regional Fire Safe Council (VRFSC) to help facilitate the inclusion of communities most at risk of wildfire in the upcoming revision of the Ventura County Community Wildfire Protection Plan (CWPP).

articles.title: Supporters
articles.contents:
Our work is supported in part by Wonder Labs. We are a member of their 2021 Reimagining 2025: Living with Fire Design challenge cohort.

Our work is also supported by generosity of the Dipaola Foundation.

articles.title: Our Team
articles.contents:
The Kindling Equity student team are all second year Masters of Environmental Science and Management (MESM) students at the Bren School of Environmental Science & Management at the University of California, Santa Barbara.
Bri Baker

A Ventura County local, Bri works seasonally in California wildfire management and fire ecology. She is passionate about making wildfire and wildfire hazard more approachable and better understood by the public and is excited to serve her community by helping to elevate its marginalized voices. | Linkedin |
Yvonne Dinh

Originally from the East Coast, Yvonne has little experience with fire hazard but is excited to learn how it plays a role in the daily lives of vulnerable communities. She is especially interested in exploring how spatial science and community learning can be used supplementary in natural hazard decision making. | Linkedin |
Iris Foxfoot

Originally from the foothills of the Sierra Nevada Mountains, Iris spent the past three years investigating how wildfire, drought, and climate change impact forest biodiversity in the Sierras. She is thrilled to join this project and is especially excited to amplify local voices in the wildfire planning process. | Linkedin |
Elena Ortiz

As a recent transplant to the Central Coast, Elena is excited to be working on a project that allows her to deeply engage with and get to know the community. She is passionate about making the environmental decision-making and planning process more equitable, and believes this project can have that kind of lasting impact in Ventura County. | Linkedin |
Alison Sells

Born and raised in Southern California, Alison grew up in close proximity to fires and is excited to learn more about the specific needs of vulnerable populations in Ventura County. She is eager to help connect with key organizations that support and represent these communities to ensure that all voices are heard in environmental decision making. | Linkedin |
Advisory Board
Our internal advisory team includes Dr. Sarah Anderson and PhD. student Louis Graup.
Our external advisors are Kate Furlong and Elaine Himmelfarb (Ventura Regional Fire Safe Council), Dr. Max Moritz (UCSB affiliate), Celine Moomey (Ventura County Fire Department).
